    ovltools

    Seongyong Park

    2020-08-20

    ovltools.Rmd

    Introduction

    ovltools designed to provide some of functions that can calculate distribution overlap between two numeric vectors. It also provides significance testing based on permutation, to assess whether given sample distributions are drawn from the same distribution or not. Current version of ovltools provides KNN (K-Nearest Neighbor), KDE (Kernel Density Estimation), histogram, distribution fitting based overlap estimation methods.

    Deviation Example

    Suppose we have one standard normal distributions \(\mathcal{N}(0,1)\) and series of standard normal distribution \(\mathcal{N}(0+dx, 1)\). Here \(dx\) ranges from \(-5\) to \(5\) by \(0.01\). Thus, we have \(1,000 + 1\) distributions in second case. Let’s suppose we want to calculate overlap between first distribution and each of second distribution. The ovltools provides existing solutions of this problem in one package.

    library(ovltools)

## Deviation Experiments
distfit = histogram = kde = rv = ks = c()
dx = seq(-5, 5, 0.05)
for(i in 1:length(dx)){
  x1 = rnorm(100)
  x2 = rnorm(100, 0+dx[i])
  tmp_rv = ovl_knn(x1, x2, k=5)
  tmp_kde = ovl_kde(x1, x2)
  tmp_hist = ovl_hist(x1, x2)
  tmp_ks = 1-ks.test(x1,x2)$statistic
  tmp_distfit = ovl_distfit(x1, x2, "norm")
  rv = c(rv, tmp_rv)
  kde = c(kde, tmp_kde)
  histogram = c(histogram, tmp_hist)
  distfit = c(distfit, tmp_distfit)
  ks = c(ks, tmp_ks)
}

## Theoretical value of overlap based on CDF and PDF.
cum_df = 2 * pnorm(-(abs(dx-0))/(2*1))
prob_df = 2 * dnorm(-(abs(dx-0))/(2*1))

## Visualize with ggplot
library(dplyr)
#> 
#> 떎쓬쓽 뙣궎吏瑜 遺李⑺빀땲떎: 'dplyr'
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats':
#> 
#>     filter, lag
#> The following objects are masked from 'package:base':
#> 
#>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)
RvMat = data.frame(dx, prob_df, cum_df, rv, kde, histogram, distfit, ks)
colnames(RvMat) = c("dx", "PDF", "CDF", "KNN", "KDE", "Hist", "DistFit", "KS")
RvMat %>% tidyr::gather(method, value, -dx) %>%
  mutate(method=factor(method,
                       levels=c("CDF", "PDF", "KS", "Hist",
                                "DistFit", "KDE", "KNN"))) %>%
  ggplot2::ggplot(aes(x=dx, y=value, col=method)) +
  geom_point() +
  theme_bw() +
  xlab("Deviation") +
  ylab("value")

    • CDF: Cumulative Distribution Function

    • PDF: Probability Distribution Function

    • KS: Kolomogrov-Smirnov Test Statistic

    • Hist: Histogram

    • DistFit: Distribution Fitting

    • KDE: Kernel Density Estimation

    • KNN: K-Nearest Neighbor

    Random Sampling Example

    Now suppose we want to perform \(N=1,000\) random sampling to estimate overlap between two distributions, \(\mathcal{N}(0,1)\) and \(\mathcal{N}(1,1)\). We can perform this experiment as previous with ovltools. Here I compared ovl_kde with existing package called overlapping and ovl_knn with Rvalue which is proposed in computers, 2019.

    library(ovltools)
library(overlapping)
#> 븘슂븳 뙣궎吏瑜 濡쒕뵫以묒엯땲떎: testthat
#> 
#> 떎쓬쓽 뙣궎吏瑜 遺李⑺빀땲떎: 'testthat'
#> The following object is masked from 'package:tidyr':
#> 
#>     matches
#> The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':
#> 
#>     matches

## Deviation Experiments
distfit = histogram = kde = kde_by_package = rv_from_src = ks = rv = c()
for(i in 1:100){
  x1 = rnorm(100)
  x2 = rnorm(100, 1)
  tmp_rv = ovl_knn(x1, x2, k=5)
  tmp_kde = ovl_kde(x1, x2)
  tmp_hist = ovl_hist(x1, x2)
  tmp_distfit = ovl_distfit(x1, x2, "norm")
  tmp_ks = 1-ks.test(x1,x2)$statistic
  rv = c(rv, tmp_rv)
  kde = c(kde, tmp_kde)
  kde_by_package = c(kde_by_package, overlap(list(x1, x2))$OV)
  rv_from_src = c(rv_from_src, Rvalue(c(x1,x2), c(rep(0,length(x1)), rep(1,length(x2)))))
  histogram = c(histogram, tmp_hist)
  distfit = c(distfit, tmp_distfit)
  ks = c(ks, tmp_ks)
}

## Theoretical value of overlap based on CDF and PDF.
cum_df = 2 * pnorm(-(abs(1-0))/(2*1))
prob_df = 2 * dnorm(-(abs(1-0))/(2*1))

## Visualize with ggplot
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(ggplot2)

RvMat = data.frame(prob_df, cum_df, rv, rv_from_src, distfit, kde, kde_by_package, histogram, ks)
colnames(RvMat) = c("PDF", "CDF", "KNN", "Rvalue", "DistFit", "KDE", "KDE_pkg", "Hist", "KS")
RvMat %>% gather(method, value) %>%
  mutate(method=factor(method,
                       levels=c("CDF", "PDF", "KS", "Hist", "DistFit",
                                "KDE", "KDE_pkg", "KNN", "Rvalue"))) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x=method, y=value, col=method)) +
  geom_violin() +
  geom_jitter(shape=16, position=position_jitter(0.2))+
  theme_bw() +
  xlab("methods") +
  ylab("value")

    As you may see in the figure, implementation in ovltools are essentially the same as the implemted functions in other packages. It is worth to say that histogram based overlap estimation is the most closely estimate true CDF overlap except distribution fitting. However distribution fitting needs to a priori knowledge about the underlying distribution. Therefore, histogram based method is generally better than other methods. Kolomogrov-smirnov test statistic \(D\) provide similar trends but since it calculates maximum distance between two CDFs, it did not match with true overlap between two CDFs.
